question: I have had COVID-19, do I still need to get the vaccine?
answer:
• According to the CDC – reinfection with COVID-19 is still possible.
  • The vaccine should be considered regardless of whether you already had the COVID-19 infection.

question: When will there be a vaccine for our kids?
answer:
• Several companies have begun enrolling children as young as age 12 in COVID-19 vaccine clinical trials.
  • Studies including younger children will begin soon.
  • Currently the COVID-19 vaccine is only available to people age 16 and older.

question: Will the COVID-19 vaccination protect me from getting COVID?
answer: • Yes - The COVID-19 vaccination works by teaching your immune system how to recognize and fight the virus that causes COVID-19, and this protects you from getting sick with COVID-19.

question: What type of side effects may occur and will they require me to miss work or have someone care for me?
answer:
• Most people experience mild side affects.
  • Your arm may be sore, red and warm to touch.
  • Others have reported headaches or fever. This is a sign that your immune system is working and building up protection to the disease.

question: Am I still a spreader if I have had COVID and/or if I have had my vaccine?
answer:
• Yes. - It takes several weeks to build up vaccine-induced antibodies and other immune defenses, and both vaccines from Pfizer and Moderna require a booster dose 21 to 28 days after the first dose. So, the full protection offered by the vaccines would take at least a month to develop.
  • And since the vaccines don’t work perfectly, and it’s not known yet to what extent they prevent infection, it’s possible that a vaccinated person might still get the virus and be able to pass it on to others.
  • People will still need to wear masks, socially distance, wash their hands and avoid large gatherings, especially indoors.
  • It will take time to vaccinate everyone. Until that happens and until it’s clear how well the vaccines prevent transmission, safety measures are still needed.

question: Why do I still have to wear a mask after I am vaccinated?
answer: • We can be immune and still be a carrier.

update:
COVID Testing Information

Weiser Memorial Hospital’s Emergency Department and Family Medical Center are facing mounting demands for COVID-19 testing, which is rapidly depleting testing supplies.

Weiser Memorial Hospital is not testing if you do not have symptoms. Weiser Memorial Hospital is not testing people who are wanting a test for travel or to attend an event.

If you are ill and need urgent medical care, go to the emergency department. A medical professional will evaluate you to determine if you need to be tested for COVID-19.

If you have mild Covid symptoms, and do not need urgent or emergency medical care, please do not come to the emergency department/Hospital for a Covid test. See testing site options below.
